bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 163, Number 123 (Thursday, July 20, 2017)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BUDD:H.R. 3321.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3, granting authority toregulate interstate commerce and commerce with foreignnations, along with Article I, Section 8, Clause 18, grantingauthority to make all laws that are necessary and proper forexecuting the foregoing.[Page H6146]

item.title: To require the President to develop a national strategy for combating the financing of terrorism and related forms of illicit finance, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

summary.text:
National Strategy for Combating Terrorist, Underground, and Other Illicit Financing Act

This bill directs the Department of the Treasury to develop a national strategy to combat the financing of terrorism and related forms of illicit finance.

bill.title: National Strategy for Combating Terrorist, Underground, and Other Illicit Financing Act

item.title: National Strategy for Combating Terrorist, Underground, and Other Illicit Financing Act
To require the establishment of a national strategy for combating the financing of terrorism and related financial crimes, and for other purposes.
National Strategy for Combating Terrorist, Underground, and Other Illicit Financing Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
